text:
I would like to contribute tasks to interact with the MKS Source Integrity 
version control product. 

According to existing conventions, I would suggest the package 
org.apache.tools.ant.taskdefs.optional.mkssi ("si" is because MKS has another 
product called Integrity Manager).

Please let me know how to proceed.

Thanks,
Vadim.
creator: vadim.hiekin@ssa.gov

text:
Created attachment 3813
Documentation for MKS tasks

Darcy, Sorry for not having replied to your question. I just did not pay 
attention to it.

What is your position about actually offering these downloads from your site ?

I figure out that you may prefer actually to be shipped as a default with Ant 
for some sort of 'free ad', but our position in the last year has been to 
actually push as much as possible the maintenance of COTS-related tasks 
outside Ant.

The problem that may happen is that your tasks will end up not being 
maintained and maybe not working with the latest release, as for example the 
Sitraka tasks and the Websphere one with the current Ant version. Add to this 
the fury of merge/acquisition between companies these days and this quickly 
become deprecated or not functional.

There are no committers using MKS Integrity, and the release date are 
obviouslly differents, this may obviouslly cause problems.

Having the Ant tasks on your side you will be able to enhance and maintain 
them quickly always in sync with your product.

Thoughts ?
creator: sbailliez@apache.org
stevel@apache.org
text:
I thought the same, but Darcy has given us the source, which is always
appreciable.  What would be nice would be some commitment by Darcy and
colleagues to maintain this. For example I may be moving from CVS to MKS at some
indeterminate time in the future...

We do of course need junit tests: Darcy: look at the ant_task_guidelines which
you should find in your docs dir; that explains things. To do the docs we could
have used proposal/xdocs to generate it from the javadocs, so the javadocs need
to be filled in with the text that becomes the end user documentation. I'd be
tempted to put the documentation into the files that way and autogen the docs,
as that is (probably) the future for all Ant tasks.

It's up to you, of course.  This is intended as an open source project (I was 
somewhat arbitrary in picking commands and parameters I thought would make 
useful tasks or attributes.  There are a whole lot more people might find 
useful).  We don't really want to support it.  I don't mind writing fixes or 
answering questions, but we don't want to do formal QA cycles or train support 
staff.  

I'm also not too worried about getting out of sync with our releases.  We may 
add new commands and parameters, but we aren't too likely to change our command 
line interface in such away that it would break scripts.

I'll putter around with junit and look into that xdocs thing, shall I?
